facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 508 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 508 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 23, 1959 of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 110 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 23, 1959 of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 110 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on November 29, 1962 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 29. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-This appeal is against an order of the High Court of Bombay issuing a writ whereby the Municipal Corporation.

facts.text: Municipal Corporation of Nagpur passed a resolution proposing to send two of its members as delegates to a Health Congress at Harrogate in UK and sanctioning certain expenses.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against an order of the High Court of Bombay issuing a writ whereby the Municipal Corporation. of Nagpur, the appellant before us, was restrained from carrying out a resolution proposing to send two of its members as delegates to a Health Congress at Harrogate in K.

facts.text: Bombay High Court issued a writ restraining the Municipal Corporation of Nagpur from carrying out the resolution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against an order of the High Court of Bombay issuing a writ whereby the Municipal Corporation. of Nagpur, the appellant before us, was restrained from carrying out a resolution

facts.text: Convenors of the Congress at Harrogate sent an invitation to the Municipal Corporation of Nagpur to send delegates.

anchor.surface_text: Now, s. 58  s  of the Act provides, The Corporation may in its discretion provides from time to time either wholly or partly for all or any of the following matters, namely -  s  any other matter likely to promote the public health, safety and companyvenience of the public. The question is whether the action of the appellant Corporation is within this section. It appears that the companyvenors of the Congress at Harrogate had sent an invitation to the appellant Corporation to send delegates to the Congress.

facts.text: Health Congress at Harrogate involved delegates discussing subjects of common interest in public health, a health exhibition, and visits to water supply undertakings, sewage disposal works, housing schemes, hospitals, health service centres, food factories and canteens.

anchor.surface_text: The following facts appear from the invitation delegates representing all aspects of public health would discuss at the Congress subjects of companymon interest there would be a health exhibition where latest equipment and products of leading manufacturers and trade and research organisations would be put on show and the delegates might visit water supply undertaking, sewage disposal works, housing schemes, hospitals, health service companytres, food factories and canteens and similar organisations.

facts.text: Health Congress at Harrogate was held from April 27 to May 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the Congress was held from April 27, to May 1, 1959 and the writ was issued by the High Court on April 23, 1959.

facts.text: Over 2,600 people attended the previous Health Congress.

anchor.surface_text: We have numberreason to think that the subjects to be discussed at the Congress were highly technical. That it would number have been so, appears to us clear from the fact that a very large gathering was expected at the Congress,, over 2,600 having attended at the previous one.

facts.text: High Court viewed that there was no reasonable and legitimate connection between sending delegates to the Congress and promotion of public health at Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: As we understand the judgment of the High Court, it does number seem to have felt much doubt about this. The High Court appears, however, to have taken the view that there was numberreasonable and legitimate companynection between the sending of the delegates to the Congress and the promotion of public health at Nagpur.

facts.text: High Court was sceptical of benefits because subjects were highly technical and proposed delegates were non-technical men, namely lawyers.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the High Court seems to have been sceptical of the benefit to be derived from the delegation because the subjects to be discussed at the Congress were, in its opinion, highly technical and the delegates proposed to be sent being number- technical men, namely, lawyers, were number likely to be in a position to follow the discussion.

facts.text: High Court held that capacity of Municipal Corporation to make use of knowledge gained at Congress was extremely limited.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also said that the capacity of the appellant Corporation to make use of the knowledge gained at the Congress was extremely limited.

facts.text: High Court held that there was no provision in the budget for expenses of sending delegation abroad.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also relied on certain sections dealing with the budget. It was said that there was numberprovision in the budget for expenses of sending a delegation abroad.

facts.text: Budget had a head dealing with allowances payable to members of the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, we are pot sure that the budget did number provide for such expenses. There was a head in it which dealt with allowances payable to the members of the Corporation.

facts.text: Petition for writ did not say that resolution was bad because expenses sanctioned were outside the budget.

anchor.surface_text: We think it right also to point out that in the petition for the writ it had number been said that the resolution was bad because the expenses sanctioned by it were outside the budget.

facts.text: High Court held that Municipal Corporation had acted honestly and circumstances did not warrant inference of mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: We think it rights to point out that the high Court held that the appellant Corporation had acted honestly. It observed that the circumstances did number warrant the inference that the action of the Corporation was mala fide.

facts.text: City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948 contains section 58(5) authorizing Corporation to provide for any other matter likely to promote public health, safety and convenience.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, the appellant Corporation had power under its incorporating statute, the City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948, to send delegates to the Congress at Harrogate, it would appear prima facie that writ was erroneously issued by the High Court. Now, s. 58  s  of the Act provides, The Corporation may in its discretion provides from time to time either wholly or partly for all or any of the following matters, namely -  s  any other matter likely to promote the public health, safety and companyvenience of the public.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, and the action proposed being clearly within the statutory powers of the appellant Corporation, we think that the High Court was in error in issuing the writ. ... We allow the appeal.

facts.text: Section 84 of the Act prohibits payment out of municipal funds unless expenditure covered by budget.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 84 of the incorporating statute, numberpayment can be made out of the municipal funds unless the expenditure is companyered by the budget.

facts.text: Section 88 of the Act gives power to transfer amount from one budget grant to another maintaining certain balance.

anchor.surface_text: But assume, they are number. Section 88 of the Act gives the Corporation power to transfer the amount of one budget grant from one major head to another provided however a certain balance is maintained in the budget.

facts.text: Respondents argued that question raised had become academic since Congress was over.

anchor.surface_text: We may number numberice one or two points of minor importance argued at the bar on behalf of the respondents. It was said that the question raised in-this appeal had become academic since the Congress was long over.

Now, s. 58  s  of the Act provides, The Corporation may in its discretion provides from time to time either wholly or partly for all or any of the following matters, namely -  s  any other matter likely to promote the public health, safety and companyvenience of the public.

issues.text: The question is whether the action of the appellant Corporation is within this section [s.58(s)]

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the action of the appellant Corporation is within this section. It appears that the convenors of the Congress at Harrogate had sent an invitation to the appellant Corporation to send delegates to the Congress. The following facts appear from the invitation delegates representing all aspects of public health would discuss at the Cong

issues.text: Whether the courts should interfere with the mode in which the Corporation decides to act if authorised by statute

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that if what a Corporation proposes to do is what it had been authorised by its incorporating statute to do, it is not the business of a court to interfere with the mode in which the Corporation decides to act see Mayor, etc. of Westminster v. London and North Western Railway Company 1 . If, therefore, the appellant Corporation had power under its incorporating statute, the City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948, to send delegates to the Congress at Harrogate, it would appear prima facie that writ was erroneously issued by the High Court.

issues.text: Whether there was a reasonable and legitimate connection between the sending of the delegates to the Congress and the promotion of public health at Nagpur under s.58(s)

anchor.surface_text: As we understand the judgment of the High Court, it does not seem to have felt much doubt about this. The High Court appears, however, to have taken the view that there was no reasonable and legitimate connection between the sending of the delegates to the Congress and the promotion of public health at Nagpur. It is somewhat difficult to appreciate the High Courts point of view.

issues.text: Whether the resolution sanctioning expenses for the delegation was beyond powers due to lack of budget provision under s.84

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also relied on certain sections dealing with the budget. It was said that there was no provision in the budget for expenses of sending a delegation abroad. Under s. 84 of the incorporating statute, no payment can be made out of the municipal funds unless the expenditure is covered by the budget. The High Court, therefore, observed that the resolution sanctioning expenses for the sending of the delegation abroad was beyond the powers of the appellant Corporation.

issues.text: Whether the action of the Corporation was mala fide

anchor.surface_text: We think it right also to point out that the high Court held that the appellant Corporation had acted honestly. It observed that the circumstances did not warrant the inference that the action of the Corporation was mala fide.

issues.text: Whether the question had become academic or moot since the Congress was over, unfit for decision under Art.136

anchor.surface_text: We may not notice one or two points of minor importance argued at the bar on behalf of the respondents. It was said that the question raised in-this appeal had become academic since the Congress was long over. It may be stated that the Congress was held from April 27, to May 1, 1959 and the writ was issued by the High Court on April 23, 1959.

issues.text: Whether s.58(s) can be interpreted to include sending delegations not in contemplation when the Act was passed in 1948

anchor.surface_text: It is also said that in 1948 when the City of Nagpur Corporation Act was passed, these delegations were not in contemplation. Therefore, s. 58(s) cannot be interpreted as including promotion of public health by sending of delegations. This is, in our view, a completely idle contention.

arguments.claim: If a corporation proposes to do what it has been authorised by its incorporating statute to do, it is not the business of a court to interfere with the mode in which the Corporation decides to act

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that if what a Corporation proposes to do is what it had been authorised by its incorporating statute to do, it is not the business of a court to interfere with the mode in which the Corporation decides to act see Mayor, etc. of Westminster v. London and North Western Railway Company 1 .

arguments.claim: The action of the appellant Corporation in sending delegates to the Health Congress is within section 58(s) of the City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948 as it promotes public health

anchor.surface_text: Now, s. 58 s of the Act provides, The Corporation may in its discretion provides from time to time either wholly or partly for all or any of the following matters, namely - s any other matter likely to promote the public health, safety and convenience of the public. The question is whether the action of the appellant Corporation is within this section.

holdings.text: If what a Corporation proposes to do is what it had been authorised by its incorporating statute to do, it is not the business of a court to interfere with the mode in which the Corporation decides to act.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that if what a Corporation proposes to do is what it had been authorised by its incorporating statute to do, it is not the business of a court to interfere with the mode in which the Corporation decides to act see Mayor, etc. of Westminster v. London and North Western Railway Company  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies established precedent from Westminster case that courts refrain from interfering in corporate exercise of statutory powers.

holdings.text: The sending of delegates to the Congress was something which the appellant Corporation was authorised by section 58(s) of its incorporating statute to do.

anchor.surface_text: appears to us plain that by sending delegates to the Congress, the appellant Corporation would have acquired useful knowledge connected with public health which it could utilise later to promote public health at Nagpur. The sending of delegates, therefore, was something which the appellant Corporation was authorised by section 58  s  of its incorporating statute to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Knowledge gained from congress on public health matters falls under 'any other matter likely to promote the public health' via purposive interpretation of broad statutory language.

holdings.text: There is reasonable and legitimate connection between the sending of the delegation to the Congress and the provisions of s. 58(s).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view of the High Court that there is no reasonable or legitimate connection between the sending of the delegation to the Congress and the provisions of s. 58  s  which we have earlier set out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's skepticism; invitation details show clear benefits for public health promotion at Nagpur.

holdings.text: It is not for this Court to decide how the delegation should have been constituted so that the appellant Corporation might have had the largest benefit from it.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is not for this Court to decide how the delegation should have been constituted so that the appellant Corporation might have had the largest benefit from it. It was for the Corporation to decide how the thing which it had the power to do was to be done.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporation's discretion in mode of exercise; no basis to find zero benefit.

holdings.text: There was no warrant to issue the writ on the ground of want of capacity of the Corporation to make use of knowledge gained.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also said that the capacity of the appellant Corporation to make use of the knowledge gained at the Congress was extremely limited. There are no materials on the record on which this observation can be justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No record evidence; Corporation can enhance capacity and would be better positioned post-delegation.

holdings.text: The resolution sanctioning expenses for the sending of the delegation abroad was not beyond the powers of the appellant Corporation; s.84 does not invalidate the resolution itself.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, we are not sure that the budget did not provide for such expenses. There was a head in it which dealt with allowances payable to the members of the Corporation. ... Furthermore, we are not sure that s. 84 would have made the resolution invalid. That section only prohibits an expenditure for which the budget does not provide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Budget head for allowances may cover; s.88 permits transfers; not pleaded in writ petition; s.84 bars payment, not resolution.

holdings.text: The circumstances did not warrant the inference that the action of the Corporation was mala fide; Corporation acted honestly.

anchor.surface_text: We think it right also to point out that the high Court held that the appellant Corporation had acted honestly. It observed that the circumstances did not warrant the inference that the action of the Corporation was mala fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court's finding; no evidence of bad faith.

holdings.text: The question raised is not academic and is fit for decision in appeal under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: We are not at all impressed by this contention. It seems to us that it is a matter of the utmost importance for the appellant Corporation to know its rights under its incorporating statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue of statutory powers vital for future guidance; prevents repeated mootness arguments.

holdings.text: Statutes in general words are not confined to thoughts prevalent at enactment time but embrace future innovations.

anchor.surface_text: This is, in our view, a completely idle contention. ... statutes cannot be confined only to thoughts prevalent at the time when they were enacted. They are put in general words to embrace innovations as they come along.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects historical limitation; broad language applies prospectively.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in issuing the writ; appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, and the action proposed being clearly within the statutory powers of the appellant Corporation, we think that the High Court was in error in issuing the writ. ... We allow the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Action authorised under statute; no grounds for interference upheld.
